summary_points: 1. Palantir Technologies Inc.'s 2025 annual meeting on June 5, 2025, resulted in the election of all director nominees and the ratification of Ernst & Young as the independent registered public accounting firm for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.

2.  Significant variation in votes cast "for" each director nominee was observed, ranging from approximately 2,779,741,753 to 3,255,395,160 votes, as of the close of business on April 11, 2025 (the Record Date).
3. The filing reveals a significant number of broker non-votes (414,188,876) across all director elections, potentially impacting the outcome of future shareholder votes.

1. On June 9, 2025, American Water Works Company, Inc.'s Board of Directors expanded from eight to nine members, appointing Raffiq Nathoo as an independent director with a term ending at the 2026 Annual Meeting of Shareholders.

2. Mr. Nathoo's compensation includes a $120,000 annual cash retainer and a prorated portion of $175,000 in annual equity compensation, vesting immediately,  with a stock ownership requirement of at least five times his annual cash retainer by June 2030.
3.  The appointment of Mr. Nathoo, with his extensive experience in international finance and the utilities sector, is expected to strengthen the board's expertise.
Failed to analyze filing
1. Mark Patterson, appointed Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer on May 14, 2025, was granted 47,832 restricted stock units (RSUs) vesting over three years with a one-year cliff.
2. This 8-K filing, dated June 9, 2025, reports on a compensatory arrangement for a newly appointed officer, as previously disclosed in a May 14, 2025 filing.
3.  The RSUs granted to Mr. Patterson are subject to the terms and conditions of the Cisco Systems, Inc. 2005 Stock Incentive Plan and form of stock unit agreement.
1. Randy Breaux retired as Group President, GPC North America, effective August 1, 2025,  with Alain Masse appointed to the newly created position of President, North American Automotive.

2. Alain Masse will receive an annual base salary of $650,000, a short-term incentive target of 90% of his base salary (pro-rated), and a long-term incentive award with an estimated target total value of $1,500,000.
3.  Mr. Breaux will remain a strategic advisor until December 31, 2025, to ensure a smooth transition.

1. At the June 5, 2025 Annual Meeting, PayPal Holdings, Inc. stockholders approved an amendment to the 2015 Equity Incentive Award Plan, increasing the number of shares reserved for issuance by 15 million.
2.  The stockholder proposal to reduce the threshold to call a special meeting of stockholders was not approved at the June 5, 2025 Annual Meeting, receiving 43.9% of the vote.
3. The June 5, 2025 Annual Meeting saw the election of 11 director nominees, each to serve until the 2026 Annual Meeting.
1. DaVita Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting, held on June 5th, 2025, saw approximately 90% of outstanding shares represented, voting on director elections, auditor ratification, and executive compensation.
2.  All director nominees were elected with significant support; however,  approximately 700,000 -1,500,000 shares voted against individual directors.
3. KPMG LLP was ratified as DaVita's independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
1. On June 9th, 2025, International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. appointed Virginia Drosos to its board of directors, effective June 16th, 2025.
2. Ms. Drosos' appointment to the board is not associated with any transactions exceeding $120,000 in which she has a material interest.
3. Ms. Drosos will receive compensation in accordance with the company's 2024 Proxy Statement, filed March 18th, 2025.

1. On June 5, 2025, American Electric Power Company, Inc. (AEP) completed a transaction where KKR and PSP Investments acquired a 19.9% equity interest in AEP's Ohio and Indiana Michigan transmission companies for $2.82 billion.
2. This $2.82 billion investment represents approximately 5% of AEP's total transmission rate base and will support AEP's five-year, $54 billion capital plan.
3.  AEP anticipates more than 20 gigawatts of new power demand and connection requests from nearly 180 gigawatts of energy demand by the end of the decade.
1. On June 9, 2025, Procter & Gamble appointed Craig Arnold, former CEO of Eaton Corporation, to its Board of Directors.
2.  Arnold will receive the same compensation as other non-employee board members, a program detailed in P&G's August 23, 2024 proxy statement.
3. Arnold's appointment is effective June 9, 2025, and he will serve on the Audit and Compensation & Leadership Development Committees.

1. Salesforce, Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders on June 5, 2025, approved an amendment to its 2013 Equity Incentive Plan, increasing the number of shares reserved for issuance by 34 million and extending the plan's termination date to March 27, 2035.
2.  The advisory vote to approve the fiscal 2025 compensation of the Company’s named executive officers resulted in 559,529,998 votes for and 168,504,472 votes against the proposal.
3.  The stockholder approval of the 2013 Equity Incentive Plan amendment may lead to increased stock-based compensation expenses in future fiscal years.

1. On June 9, 2025, Disney finalized the acquisition of NBCU's 33% stake in Hulu for an additional $438.7 million beyond the initial $8.6 billion payment, bringing the total cost to approximately $9 billion.

2. This $438.7 million will be recorded as reducing Disney's net income attributable to Disney in the fiscal third quarter, but is expected to be excluded from Disney's Adjusted EPS and not impact prior fiscal year 2025 guidance.
3. The acquisition of NBCU's Hulu stake is expected to close on or before July 24, 2025, allowing for deeper integration of Hulu content with Disney+ and ESPN+.
1. Allegion plc held its 2025 Annual General Meeting on June 5, 2025, where shareholders elected all eight nominated directors and approved executive officer compensation (on an advisory basis).
2.  In the director election, while over 73 million votes were cast "For" each nominee,  "Against" votes ranged from 216,726 to 1,894,481.
3. The Board's authority to issue shares under Irish law, and to issue shares for cash without offering them to existing shareholders, was renewed.

1. On June 4th, 2025, Danny Deep was promoted from Executive Vice President, Combat Systems to Executive Vice President, Global Operations, with a base salary of $1,200,000 and a target annual incentive of 130% of his base salary.
2.  The filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a significant corporate event requiring immediate disclosure to the SEC.

3. Deep's long-term incentive compensation will be determined according to the company's 2025 proxy statement (filed March 28th, 2025), which introduces potential future risks related to equity-based compensation.
1. On June 9, 2025, GE HealthCare Technologies Inc. issued $650,000,000 of 4.800% Senior Notes due 2031 and $850,000,000 of 5.500% Senior Notes due 2035.
2.  The issuance of the notes brings the total principal amount to $1,500,000,000.
3.  The notes are subject to optional redemption and a potential repurchase upon a Change of Control Repurchase Event, as defined within the filing's indenture.
Failed to analyze filing
1. Qualcomm is acquiring Alphawave IP Group plc in a recommended acquisition, where Alphawave shareholders can choose between cash or Qualcomm stock/exchangeable securities as payment.

2.  If all eligible Alphawave shareholders elect for stock-based compensation and all exchangeable securities are converted, approximately 15,575,072 Qualcomm shares (1.4% of outstanding shares as of April 28, 2025) may be issued.

3. The acquisition's completion is subject to various conditions, including regulatory approvals, posing a risk of failure or delays;  further risks are detailed in Qualcomm’s Form 10-K and subsequent 10-Q filings.
1. On June 9th, 2025, AIG upsized its cash tender offers to purchase outstanding notes from $300 million to $455 million, and accepted $457.14 million in principal amount of notes for purchase.
2.  As of the June 6th, 2025 expiration date, $475.86 million in principal amount of notes were validly tendered and not withdrawn from the tender offer, exceeding the original $300 million limit.
3.  AIG did not accept notes with Acceptance Priority Levels 9 or 10, and promptly returned these validly tendered notes to the holders.

1. Workday, Inc.'s Annual Meeting of Stockholders on June 4, 2025, saw the election of four new Class I directors (Carl M. Eschenbach, Michael M. McNamara, Michael L. Speiser, and Jerry Yang) to serve until the 2028 Annual Meeting.
2.  The shareholder vote to ratify Ernst & Young LLP as Workday's independent auditor for fiscal year 2026 (ending January 31, 2026) passed with 700,336,276 votes for, and 3,622,282 votes against.
3.  Shareholders provided advisory approval of Workday's named executive officer compensation, with 588,150,492 votes for and 94,924,689 votes against.
Failed to analyze filing
1. McKesson Corporation increased its Fiscal Year 2026 Adjusted Earnings per Diluted Share guidance from $36.75 to $37.55 to a new range of $36.90 to $37.70 on June 9th, 2025.
2.  The company anticipates a higher effective tax rate in the first quarter of Fiscal Year 2026 (17% to 20%) than in the second quarter (16% to 19%), with a full-year range of 17% to 19%.

3. McKesson faces numerous future risks, including costly legal disputes, uninsured losses, changing healthcare regulations, cybersecurity incidents, and difficulties achieving strategic growth objectives.
1. Warner Bros. Discovery plans to separate into two publicly traded companies, Streaming & Studios and Global Networks, by mid-2026.
2.  A $17.5 billion bridge loan (potentially reaching $20 billion) will finance a $14.6 billion debt refinancing as part of this separation.
3. The planned separation is contingent upon board approval, tax opinions, and favorable market conditions, with potential delays or failure if these conditions aren't met.

1. FirstEnergy Corp. plans to offer $950 million of convertible senior notes due 2029 and $850 million due 2031 in a private placement to qualified institutional buyers, with options for an additional $300 million aggregate principal amount.

2.  The net proceeds from the convertible note offering are intended to be used for repurchasing existing 4.00% convertible senior notes due May 1, 2026, repaying existing debt, general corporate purposes, or a combination thereof.
3. The offering is subject to market conditions and other factors, and there's a risk the offering may not be consummated as planned, impacting the company's debt structure and financial flexibility.
